title-group.article-title: The Comparison between Cemented and Uncemented Hemiarthroplasty in Patients with Femoral Neck Fractures: A Systematic Review and Meta‐analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

aff.named-content: West China School of Nursing, Sichuan University / Department of Orthopedics, West China Hospital
Institute of Hospital Management West China Hospital

author-notes.corresp: *Address for correspondence Lingli Li, Ph.D, and Pengcheng Li, Ph.D, West China School of Nursing, Sichuan University/Department of Orthopedics, West China Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu, 610041, P.R. China; Email: lilingli2000@126.com; 16699411@qq.com

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Hemiarthroplasty is the standard treatment for patients with femoral neck fractures (FNFs). Controversy exists over the use of bone cement in hip fractures treated with hemiarthroplasty.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: We performed an updated systematic review and meta‐analysis to compare cemented and uncemented hemiarthroplasty in patients with femoral neck fractures.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A literature review was conducted using Cochrane Library, ScienceDirect, PubMed, Embase, Medline, Web of Science, CNKI, VIP, Wang Fang, and Sino Med databases. Studies comparing cemented with uncemented hemiarthroplasty for FNFs in elderly patients up to June 2022 were included. Data were extracted, meta‐analyzed, and pooled as risk ratios (RRs) and weighted mean differences (WMDs) with a 95% confidence interval (95% CI).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Twenty‐four RCTs involving 3471 patients (1749 cement; 1722 uncemented) were analyzed. Patients with cemented intervention had better outcomes regarding hip function, pain, and complications. Significant differences were found in terms of HHS at 6 weeks (WMD 12.5; 95% CI 6.0–17.0; P < 0.001), 3 months (WMD 3.3; 95% CI 1.6–5.0; P < 0.001), 4 months (WMD 7.3; 95% CI 3.4–11.2; P < 0.001), and 6 months (WMD 4.6; 95% CI 3.3–5.8; P < 0.001) postoperatively. Patients with cemented hemiarthroplasty had lower rates of pain (RR 0.59; 95% CI 0.39–0.9; P = 0.013), prosthetic fracture (RR 0.24; 95% CI 0.16–0.38; P < 0.001), subsidence/loosening (RR 0.29; 95% CI 0.11–0.78; P = 0.014), revisions (RR 0.59; 95% CI 0.40–0.89; P = 0.012), and pressure ulcers (RR 0.43; 95% CI 0.23–0.82; P = 0.01) at the expense of longer surgery time (WMD 7.87; 95% CI 5.71–10.02; P < 0.001).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This meta‐analysis demonstrated that patients with cemented hemiarthroplasty had better results in hip function and pain relief and lower complication rates at the expense of prolonged surgery time. Cemented hemiarthroplasty is recommended based on our findings.

abstract.p: The individual and overall risk of bias of included studies showing that the overall risk of bias is moderate; and the overall selection process showing the detailed information of studies enrolled and excluded.

Sichuan University Postdoctoral Interdisciplinary Innovation Fund.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Femoral neck fracture (FNF) among elderly patients is a global problem that not only impairs patients' quality of life but also exerts a substantial burden on the national health care system. 1 It has been estimated that cases of FNFs in European countries will increase to 7 million per year by 2050. 2 Data showed that more than 10% of patients died within 30 days, and more than 30% of them died in 1 year if patients with FNFs did not receive appropriate medical interventions. 3 , 4 Hemiarthroplasty (HA) was used to treat FNFs in elderly, cognitively impaired, and less mobile patients and enable them to relieve postoperative pain and regain mobility. 5 If the implant is not securely bonded to the patient's bone, it can loosen, causing pain and restricting activities of daily living. There are two types of hemiarthroplasty: cemented hemiarthroplasty (CHA) and uncemented hemiarthroplasty (UCHA). 6 There remains controversy about how best to fix the hemiarthroplasty implant to the bone of the femur. 7

Eight meta‐analyses were published, but the results were inconsistent. 6 , 8 , 9 , 10 , 11 , 12 , 13 , 14 , 15 Some reviews have shown equivalent complication outcomes, while others have shown lower complication rates with cemented hemiarthroplasty. Most studies were based on a pooled analysis of few trials and restricted by the lack of insufficient samples, reducing the ability to obtain dependable conclusions. Ahn et al. 15 identified 11 studies, including both prospective and retrospective studies, and concluded that patients with CHA had a lower revision rate, while those with UCHA had less blood loss and shorter surgery time. 15 Imam et al. summarized nine RCTs and 20 observations and found a higher volume of intraoperative blood loss and a higher rate of heterotopic ossification in CHA. 11 These reviews were limited by predictable bias from quasi‐RCTs or non‐RCTs and had considerable heterogeneity in most outcomes. The pooled results were mixed with quasi‐RCTs or non‐RCTs, which might influence the quality of synthesized evidence and lead to bias. As the first meta‐analysis only enrolled RCTs, Li et al. 14 involved seven RCTs and found that CHA was associated with better hip function, lower levels of pain, and fewer implant‐related complications in elderly patients with FNFs. In their study, funnel plots were lacking due to the limited number of trials, resulting in unknown publication bias. Ning et al. 13 published an updated meta‐analysis including 12 studies, the results clashed with previous reviews and carried a substantial risk of bias in methodology assessment. Sensitivity analysis or subgroup analysis was not used to explain the high heterogeneity in several outcomes, and complications were roughly stratified with no specific analyzed syndrome. To date, it remains unknown how and to what extent these risks of bias would influence their findings. Furthermore, these findings may not apply to modern types of implants that have been used in recent years. Several more recent trials that use contemporary implants have been published since the last relevant review in 2020 and have not been included in the previous meta‐analysis. 16 , 17 , 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 , 22

Given the continuing uncertainties, we aimed to integrate the latest evidence to provide an updated systematic review and meta‐analysis including all relevant RCTs published to date to compare the effectiveness and safety of cemented and uncemented hemiarthroplasty in elderly patients with FNFs.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This work has been reported in line with PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta‐Analyses) and the protocol was registered in PROSPERO (registration No CRD42023389558).

sec.title: Search Strategies
sec.p: Two investigators searched six English databases (Cochrane Library, ScienceDirect, PubMed, Embase, Medline, and Web of Science) and four Chinese databases (CNKI, VIP, Wang Fang, and Sino Med) in June 2022. The following search terms were searched: “Hemiarthroplasty,” “Hemiarthroplasties,” “Hemi‐Arthroplasty,” “Hemi Arthroplasty,” “Hemi‐Arthroplasties,” “Femoral Neck Fractures,” “Femoral Neck Fracture,” “Femur Neck Fractures,” “Femur Neck Fracture,” “Thompson/Austin Moore prostheses,” “cemented,” “cement,” “uncemented,” “uncemented,” and “cementless.” Searches were restricted to human studies without language restrictions. Initial screening of retrieved titles and abstracts was performed by one reviewer, followed by full‐text acquisition and detailed evaluation conducted by another two independent reviewers. References cited in relevant articles were also manually searched for relevant articles.

sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
sec.p: The inclusion criteria of studies were as follows: (i) RCTs that recruited adult patients with nonpathological FNFs (not primary or metastatic malignant lesions); (ii) trials compared cemented fixation with uncemented fixation of hemiarthroplasty (or vice versa); (iii) studies with full text and data available for further meta‐analysis; and (iv) studies that reported at least one of the following outcomes (i.e., mortality, Harris hip score [HHS], activities of daily living [ADL], short musculoskeletal function assessment questionnaire [SMFA], time up and Go [TUG], 12‐item short form survey [SF‐12], EuroQol 5 dimensions questionnaire [EQ‐5D]), revision, reoperation, postoperative complications (pneumonia, thromboembolic events (deep vein thrombosis and/or pulmonary embolism, cardiovascular complications, deep or superficial infection, fracture, dislocation, urinary tract infection, cardiac arrest, and hematoma), perioperative details (e.g., operating time and anesthesia, blood loss, blood transfusion), pain, and length of hospital stay).
Studies were excluded if they met the following items: meeting abstracts, comments, case reports, reviews, and meta‐analyses; data could not be extracted or estimated.

sec.title: Data Extraction
sec.p: Two reviewers independently extracted relevant information from each eligible study using a standard collection spreadsheet. Any disagreement was resolved by the adjudicating senior authors. When the same study was described in several publications, the most comprehensive paper was used, or nonoverlapping data were extracted. Two authors extracted the study characteristics from each included study, including the year of publication, enrollment periods, gender, number of participants in each arm, the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) scale, the number of doctors participating in the surgery, the type of implants, follow‐up time, surgical approach, and information assessing the risk of bias in the studies.

Our primary outcome was Harris hip score (HHS). Our secondary outcomes were rates of postoperative complications, which could be classified as prothesis‐related complications (i.e., revision, fracture, subsidence/loosening, dislocation, acetabular erosion, and heterotopic ossification), and general complications (i.e., pressure ulcer, deep vein thrombosis, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, renal failure, urinary tract infection, vascular disease, and wound infection). The other outcomes were perioperative indicators (i.e., total surgery time, length of hospital stay, number of patients who had mental status change, hemoglobin level at discharge, the volume of blood loss, and rate of transfusion), pain, and mortality (See Table 1).

fn.p: Note: a = Unipolar and b = bipolar.
Abbreviations: DLA, direct lateral approach; HDLA, Hardinge direct lateral approach; MPA, modified posterolateral approach; N/A, not find; PA, Posterior approach; SA, standard anterolateral approach.

sec.title: Quality Assessment
sec.p: We assessed the methodological quality of original studies using the revised Jadad scale. It included random sequences (0–2 points), randomized concealment (0–2 points), blind method (0–2 points), and the number and reasons for withdrawals or dropouts (0–1 points). The total score is 7 points, whereby 0 to 3 points are considered low quality and 4 to 7 points are considered high quality.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: We analyzed the data using STATA software, V.15.0 (STATA Corporation, College Station, TX, USA). The weighted mean difference (WMD) and relative risks (RR) were used to compare continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively. All results were reported with confidence intervals (95% CIs). For data reported as medians, ranges, and 95% CIs, means and standard deviations (SDs) were calculated. The I 2 test was used to examine heterogeneity across studies. Heterogeneity was defined as absent (I 2 = 0.0% to 25.0%), low (I 2 = 25.1% to 50.0%), moderate (I 2 = 50.1% to 75.0%), or high (I 2 = 75.1% to 100.0%). Random‐effect models were used to combine RRs to minimize the effect of heterogeneity. Publication bias was evaluated using funnel plots and Egger's regression symmetry tests. Sensitivity analysis was further performed by dropping out of each enrolled trial to assess the stability of the pooled results (when I 2 > 50%, considered statistical heterogeneity). Subgroup analysis was performed to compare the different follow‐up points to explain the origin of heterogeneity (when I 2 > 50%, statistical heterogeneity was considered). All P values were two‐sided and considered significant if P < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 1145 studies were searched by the search strategies (including academic databases and articles retrieved in reference). After automatic duplicates, 639 articles were saved. By screening the titles and abstracts, 550 studies were excluded. Full texts of the remaining 89 studies were retrieved for review. After a detailed evaluation, a total of 583 were excluded because of the following reasons: (i) exposure was not relevant (n = 381); (ii) inappropriate article types (i.e., reviews or meta‐analysis) (n = 47); (iii) not human trials (n = 13); (iv) full texts were not obtainable (n = 11); (v) retrospective studies (n = 37) or not RCTs (n = 31); and (vi) the quality of articles was considered very low quality. Finally, 24 studies were identified (Fig. 1).

caption.p: PRISMA flow diagram representing search and selection of studies comparing cementing versus uncementing hemiarthroplasty.

sec.title: Study Characteristics
sec.p: We identified 24 RCTs, with 12 conducted in North America, eight in European countries, and four in China. All selected studies were published between 1982 and 2020. There was altogether 995 female (28.67%) and 2476 male (71.33%) patients, and there was no significant difference between the two groups. A total of 3471 patients were included, with 1749 patients in the cement group and the other 1722 patients in the uncemented group. Eight studies reported the number of surgeons who finished these surgeries, while the remainder did not mention them. Implants have been grouped according to whether they are currently being used for elective total hip arthroplasty according to the National Joint Registry (NJR) 16th annual report, where the details of the implant were not reported; they were assumed to be uncemented prostheses. The duration of follow‐up ranged from 6 weeks to 4 years. The information on the included studies can be seen in Table 1.

sec.title: Risk of Bias and Publication Bias
sec.p: Twelve studies showed a high risk of bias in one domain (allocation concealment), and seven studies showed a high risk of bias in two domains (four showed a high risk of bias in random sequencing and blinding of participants and personnel; two showed a high risk of bias in the blinding of participants and personnel and outcome assessment; and one showed a high risk of bias in the blinding of participants and personnel and incomplete outcome data). The other two studies had unclear or low risks of bias. All, except for performance bias, had an unclear or low risk of bias in selection bias, detection bias, attrition bias, reporting bias, and other biases. The risk of bias regarding the methodological quality of the included studies is shown in Fig. 2. Funnel plots were used to investigate the possibility of the risk of publication bias (Fig. 3).

caption.p: The sum and individual risk of bias assessment.

sec.title: Harris Hip Scores
sec.p: The pooled analysis showed that CHA had higher HHS when followed at 6 weeks (WMD 11.52; 95% CI 6.01–17.01; P < 0.05), at 3 months (WMD 3.3; 95% CI 1.60–5.00; P < 0.05), at 4 months (WMD 7.3; 95% CI 3.37–11.23; P < 0.05), and at 6 months postoperatively (WMD 4.57, 95% CI 3.30–5.84; P < 0.05) (Fig. 3). There was no significant difference after 6 months (Table 2).

fn.p: Note: *OR or WMD considered statistically significant (P < 0.05).

Abbreviations: 95% CI, 95% confidence interval; CH, cemented hemiarthroplasty; RR, risk ratio (for dichotomous outcomes); UCH, uncemented hemiarthroplasty; WMD, weighted mean difference (for continuous outcomes). P < 0.05 was considered as statistically significant (in bold).

sec.title: Prothesis‐related Complications
sec.p: The pooled analysis showed that CHA had a lower rate of revision (RR 0.59; 95% CI 0.40–0.90; P = 0.012) with no evidence of significant heterogeneity (I 2 = 0%; P = 0.51). CHA also had lower rates of fracture (RR 0.24; 95% CI 0.16–0.38; P < 0.05) in a pooled analysis of 15 RCTs and subsidence/loosening (RR 0.22; 95% CI 0.12–0.41; P < 0.05) in a pooled analysis of nine RCTs when compared to UCHA.

There was no significant difference between the CHA and UCHA groups regarding the rates of dislocation (15 trials, 2112 patients; RR 1.08; 95% CI 0.56–2.09; P = 0.81), acetabular erosion (3 trials, 394 patients; RR 1.77; 95% CI 0.40–7.83; P = 0.78), or heterotopic ossification (5 trials, 526 patients; RR 0.98; 95% CI 0.76–1.27; P = 0.89).

sec.title: Surgical‐related Complications
sec.p: In the pooled analysis, the RR of pressure ulcers was 0.43 (95% CI 0.23 to 0.82). There was no significant difference in the rates of deep vein thrombosis (eight trials; 814 cemented vs 787 uncemented; RR 1.06; 95% CI 0.47–2.37; P = 0.90), pneumonia (15 trials; 127 cemented vs 1152 uncemented; RR 0.87; 95% CI 0.59–1.29; P = 0.49), pulmonary embolism (six trials; 702 cemented vs 678 uncemented; RR 2.52; 95% CI 0.94–6.78; P = 0.07), renal failure (five trials; RR 1.06; 95% CI, 0.45–2.52; P = 0.89), urinary tract infection (eight trials; 444 vs 438; RR 0.99; 95% CI 0.67–1.46; P = 0.97), vascular disease (11 trials; RR 1.04, 95% CI 0.70–1.57; P = 0.84), and wound infection (16 trials, 218 vs 1188; RR 1.15; 95% CI 0.76–1.73; P = 0.51).

sec.title: Operative Outcomes
sec.p: CHA was associated with longer surgery time (WMD 7.87 min; 95% CI 5.71–10.02; P < 0.05). There was no significant difference in the length of hospital stay (11 trials, 1865 patients; WMD −0.35 days; 95% CI −0.88 to 0.18; P = 0.20), the occurrence of mental status change (RR 1.01; 95% CI 0.63–1.62; P = 0.98), discharge hemoglobin level (WMD 2.0 mg; 95% CI 0.85–4.85; P = 0.17), the volume of blood loss (15 studies, 2240 patients, WMD −6.282 mL, 95% CI −28.20 to 15.63 mL; P = 0.57), and the rate of transfusion (six studies, 1682 patients, RR 1.0; 95% CI 0.81–1.24; P = 1.0).

sec.title: Pain
sec.p: The pooled results showed that CHA had a lower rate of pain occurrence (RR 0.59; 95% CI 0.39–0.90; P = 0.013). Considering the stubborn heterogeneity (I 2 = 50.5%, P = 0.023), further sensitivity analyses were performed, and two trials contributed approximately 37% of the heterogeneity. 27 , 28 After removing every single study, the results remained unchanged (RR 0.61; 95% CI 0.49–0.77; P < 0.05).

sec.title: Mortality
sec.p: The results showed no significant differences between the CHA and UCHA groups for mortality at each follow‐up point: during hospitalization (RR 1.65; 95% CI 0.88–3.08; P = 0.12), within 6 months (RR 0.99; 95% CI 0.78–1.26; P = 0.91), at 1 year (RR = 0.91; 95% CI 0.74–1.10; P = 0.33), or at 2 years postoperatively (RR 0.97; 95% CI 0.79–1.20; P = 0.81).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We conducted a meta‐analysis based on 24 RCTs and enrolled a large group of 3471 patients to date, with a comprehensive list of outcomes to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of cemented hemiarthroplasty compared with uncemented hemiarthroplasty in the treatment of femoral neck fractures. Our study showed that patients who underwent CHA had better hip function (higher HHS scores within 6 months), lower rates of prosthesis‐related complications (revision, subsidence/loosening, fractures), surgical‐related complications (pressure injury), and pain, at the expense of a prolonged time of surgery.

sec.title: Hip Function
sec.p: Our study found that patients who received cemented hemiarthroplasty had better hip function. Unlike previous reviews, 12 , 15 our study enrolled adequate data for quantitative analysis of functional outcomes, and we reported new findings. It was challenging to pool the results due to the inconsistency of outcome parameters. Therefore, we took the HHS score as a standard parameter with large samples. Most earlier reviews in this area evaluated HHS scores at undefined time points, whereas we evaluated them at seven different time points (within 6 weeks, 3 months, 4 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, and after that). In our results, we confirmed that CHA has a better hip function within 6 months and no difference after that. The possible reasons may be that bone cement forms a solid bond between the stem and bone, providing favorable biomechanical advantages and can further reduce the degree of early postoperative pain and lead to better mobility and early mobilization. Limited long‐term follow‐up trials have been conducted in our study, and we suggest that future research should enroll more long‐term follow‐up trials.

Moreover, there was a range of stools that researchers used in their study to measure the recovery of functional ability. For example, Barenius et al. 18 applied the EuroQol five dimensions questionnaire (EQ‐5D) and the short musculoskeletal function assessment (SMFA) for assessment. Their results suggest that the cemented group had better hip function recovery in the short term but deteriorated as time passed, and there were no statistically significant differences at 48 months. Khorami et al. 29 and Li et al. 20 rated HHS by grade, so we excluded their trials from our quantitative analysis. Taylor et al. 30 used the Oxford hip score (OHS) for assessment and concluded that UCH had poorer performance at 6 weeks, and the result was similar to that of Singh and Deshmukh. 31 Since the grouping is arbitrary and is not suggested by the originators, we did not synthesize them. DeAngelis et al. 32 adopted information about hip function by activities of daily living (ADL) and the energy/fatigue scale instruments. Their results showed no statistically significant difference. 32 Parker and Cawley 16 measured the patient's walking ability by a mobility scale adapted from a hip fracture mobility score, which found that the CHA group regained a better degree of mobility at 1 year, which enhanced their results published 10 years ago (in which CHA performed better at three of 16 activities of daily living). 33 The results of Moroni et al. 34 were different from the others and favored UCHA. Possible reasons were that the Furlong prosthesis added an HA coating, and the HA coating was banded with osteoporotic bone, establishing stable fixation in patients. 34 Santini et al. 35 used a total functional score (from 0 to 18 points) to evaluate the walking ability and personal daily activity and found no difference regarding total functional score (9.13 ± 6.02 in CHA, 8.95 ± 5.86 in UCH). Sonne‐holm et al. 36 assessed hip function based on a 0–6 scale questionnaire (pain, gait function, and hip mobility were measured), and found CHA had significantly better results within 6 months. Emery et al. 37 and Dorr et al.24 also found that CHA had better mobility. In Langslet et al.'s study, 38 HHS was higher in the uncemented group, but it should be interpreted cautiously due to the lost people in an extended follow‐up.

sec.title: Prothesis‐related Complications
sec.p: Other significant findings were the substantial differences between the groups in the rate of four main prosthesis‐related complications. The reduced rates of fractures, loosening, subsidence, and revisions in the CHA group were evidenced, and our results were consistent with findings from a large registry study (more than 11,000 patients). 39

The incidences of fractures were accidentally encountered during insertion or broaching when surgeons used the “press‐fit” skill in UCHA. The failure of osseointegration was considered another main reason for fractures. Subsidence/loosening of the prosthesis was also a significant issue for surgeons to consider when selecting the appropriate prosthesis for elderly individuals. The cementing technique was reported to enhance the bonding of bone and implant, therefore reducing the rates of loosening. 40 During polymerization, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) bio‐cement will generate a very high temperature, and lead to an increased risk of heat‐related tissue damage in elderly patients with chronic diseases. 41 Avoiding excessive PMMA injection and excessive pressure during injection may play a role in prevention. 42

Our meta‐analysis also demonstrates that patients in the CHA group had a lower incidence of revision, which is consistent with previous studies. 43 , 44 The specific reasons for the improved outcomes in revision have not been definitively elucidated. However, one theory is that cemented fixation may better resist periprosthetic fracture and less pain among patients with risk factors such as advanced age, osteoporosis, and/or a history of falls. 45 Therefore, we recommend prostheses that could be combined with patients' conditions (such as wider canals or poor bone quality) and technical procedures with careful steps without brutal force that could achieve tight contact between the prosthesis and the endosteal bone surface.

sec.title: Pain Relief
sec.p: Pain control was a vital component when patients had FNFs. It allows early mobilization, decreases the risks of respiratory tract infections, and reduces the risk of thromboembolism. 46 Previous studies reported a lower level of pain in the CHA group with varied RRs. 14 , 16 Our results enhanced previous findings. Pain scores usually peak at 24–36 h postoperatively, corresponding to when patients begin to sit up in bed and embark on physiotherapy and mobilization. We assumed that the cementing technique reduced the erosion between the prosthesis and bone, therefore reducing the pain level. A stubborn heterogeneity in pain score (I 2 = 50.5%, P = 0.023) was reported and we did sensitivity analyses. We found the main source heterogeneity came from two trials, 23 , 24 and the results remained unchanged (RR 0.61) after sequentially removing each study, which suggests the reliability of our study.

Moreover, there was a range of stools researchers used to measure the level of pain of 24, including RCTs, some recorded rates, some used the visual analogue scale (VAS), and some used HHS pain sub scores. Some studies cannot be qualitatively synthesized; Parker and Cawley 16 found that there was no significant difference at any time interval. In Parker and Cawley's analysis, pain scores were assessed on a scale of 1 (no pain) to 8 (constant and severe), which was modified from the Charnley score. Barenius et al. 18 found a higher mean HHS pain subscore at 24 months in the CHA group but similar scores at 4, 12, or 48 months.

sec.title: Surgical‐related Complications
sec.p: No significant difference was found between the cemented and uncemented groups except for pressure injury, which had not been reported by previous studies. Elderly individuals are usually at a high risk of pressure ulcer occurrence, and delayed mobilization may be the main reason, which we considered a possible explanation for our observation. 47 Previous studies have found that cement was linked to perioperative death, the occurrence of pulmonary embolism, and vascular complications due to cement toxicity or embolism of bone marrow contents. We found similar rates between the two groups. This may be explained by the prevailing idea of enhanced recovery after surgery, and a large number of surgeons are mobilizing patients early. 48

sec.title: Operative Outcomes and Mortality
sec.p: The only significant difference we found between the CHA and UCHA groups was surgery time (7.9 min, P < 0.001), which is consistent with other studies. The prolonged surgery time was the process of cement polymerization, insertion, and solidification waiting period.

Our study showed that the mortality was similar between the CHA and UCHA groups, which was consistent with mainstream previous reports. 6 , 9 , 49 Previous studies found that CHA was associated with a high risk of death due to bone cement implantation syndrome (BCIS) at a rate of approximately 0.5%~0.6%. 16 In the included studies, four trials reported several cases of death. 16 , 23 , 50 , 51 In a cohort study, Costain et al. 52 found a significant difference with 1‐day mortality postoperatively of 0.5% in UCHA and 0.8% in CHA (P < 0.001).

sec.title: Strengthens and Limitations of our Study
sec.p: To our knowledge, our study by far enrolled the largest sample of RCTs and demonstrated the effects of cemented and uncemented hemiarthroplasty, providing a comprehensive summary of the evidence, and was important for the formulation of treatment policies and clinical guidelines, offering orthopedic surgeons a choice of various effective strategies. In the sight of long‐term effects becoming more and more valuable (most prostheses could be used for a time of more than 10 years), our results were based on pooled data across short‐term and longer‐term outcomes, and therefore provide valuable information. Moreover, our protocol was pre‐registered and adheres to a strict review process of systematic review and meta‐analysis using wide eligibility criteria and evaluation, which ensures the reliability of our results.

Our study also had several limitations. First, studies with small sample sizes might lead to bias. Second, only published articles were included in this meta‐analysis, resulting in possible publication bias. Third, although subgroup analyses were used, the pooled results of some variables were still reported with high heterogeneity, which should be interpreted with caution. Furthermore, we did not exclude studies with criteria such as implant type of unipolar or bipolar, patient age, and modern or old stems. The latter makes our study generalizable to all patients treated with hemiarthroplasty.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our study revealed that patients undergoing cemented hemiarthroplasty were associated with better knee recovery regarding hip function, pain level, and complication rates. The only disadvantage of cement hemiarthroplasty was prolonged surgery time. However, it did not bring any risk of infection. Therefore, according to our results, cemented hemiarthroplasty was recommended for patients with hemiarthroplasty.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: HY conceived the methods of the study, and performed the database search, the article selection, and data extraction processes, TXM and LY performed the statistical analysis and drafted the manuscript. LSH, and LLL conceived the methods of the study, performed the database search, the article selection, and data extraction processes, and drafted the manuscript. LLL and LPC helped to draft the manuscript. All authors read and approved the manuscript.

sec.title: Ethical Approval
sec.p: This meta‐analysis and all the included studies meet all the ethical standards described in the declaration of Helsinki. No ethical committee approval was required for this study.

sec.title: Consent for Publication
sec.p: All authors have stated for consents of publications (include appropriate statements).

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We appreciate Dr. Angela for improving the language.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
